qas.question: Do test circuits create permanent or temporary connections between traces?
What's the most frequently used test configuration procedure for ICs?
What would you avoid by using the Joint Test Action Group standard?
What component of the printed circuit board is appraised with boundary scan testing?
To whom would you go to acquire the algorithms you'd use for the Joint Test Action Group procedures?

plausible_answers.text: that all the ICs to be tested use a standard test configuration procedure
the Joint Test Action Group (JTAG) standard

qas.question: The least common standard test configuration procedure is what?
JAG tool vendors provide various types of what?

plausible_answers.text: test interconnects between integrated circuits on a board without using physical test probes

qas.question: The JAG test architecture provides a means to what?

context: In boundary scan testing, test circuits integrated into various ICs on the board form <a0_0>temporary<a0_0/> connections between the PCB traces to test that the <a3_0>ICs<a3_0/> are mounted correctly. Boundary scan testing requires <b5_0>that all the ICs to be tested use a standard test configuration procedure<b5_0/>, the most common one being <b6_0>the <a1_0>Joint Test Action Group<a1_0/> (JTAG) standard<b6_0/>. The JTAG test architecture provides a means to <b8_0>test interconnects between integrated circuits on a board without using <a2_0>physical test probes<b8_0/><a2_0/>. <a4_0>JTAG tool vendors<a4_0/> provide various types of <b7_0>stimulus<b7_0/> and sophisticated algorithms, not only to detect the failing nets, but also to isolate the faults to specific nets, devices, and pins.
